channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Crimean Officials Claim to Secure Peninsula
item.description: Sergei Aksyonov, the prime minister of the autonomous region, offered the assurance on Tuesday even as armed standoffs continued between Russian forces and Ukrainian troops.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Citing ‘Coup’ in Ukraine, Putin Reserves Right to Use Force
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Tuesday that the Ukrainian crisis resulted from an “unconstitutional coup,” and said that any potential use of military force would be “a last resort.”
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, ELLEN BARRY and ALAN COWELL

item.title: North Korea Tests Rocket Launcher With Longer Range, South Says
item.description: South Korean military officials said the weapon tested Tuesday could reach major military bases south of Seoul.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia observed the snap military exercise he ordered last week; the United Nations Security Council prepared to meet.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Ink: Indian Cricket Team’s Problems Boil Down to Bowling, Experts Say
item.description: India’s recent emotional loss against Pakistan comes on the heels of series defeats against South Africa and New Zealand, but cricket analysts say it’s too early to write the team off.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA

item.title: In Kiev, Kerry Offers Aid in Shoring Up Ukrainian Economy
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Ukraine’s capital with $1 billion in loan guarantees meant to support the country’s efforts to integrate with the West and pledges of technical aid.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Albert Ho on Democracy and Civil Disobedience in Hong Kong
item.description: The pro-democracy legislator and lawyer says that he and many others are ready to go to jail in protest should China set conditions on who can run for chief executive of Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Albert Ho, lawyer and member of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong.

item.title: Israeli Airstrike Kills 2 in Gaza
item.description: A spokesman for the Israel Defense Forces said the strike eliminated a “real-time threat” from a group that was preparing to launch rockets into southern Israel.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Markets Rebound on Hopes of Tension Easing in Ukraine
item.description: The Russian benchmark index gained 3.2 percent on Tuesday after a 10.8 percent decline the day before, and stock markets elsewhere made up lost ground.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Michelle Obama to Stress Education on China Trip
item.description: The American first lady is to focus on “the power and importance of education” during a visit to China this month that will include a meeting with Peng Liyuan, the wife of President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Michelle Obama with her daughters, Sasha, left, and Malia, who will travel with the first lady to China this month.

item.title: India Ink: Graffiti Artists in Srinagar Aim to Go Beyond Vandalism
item.description: The young men who secretly paint on the city’s walls focus less on bashing India and more on the daily problems plaguing Kashmiri society.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Graffiti on a wall in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, by the El-Horiah group .

item.title: Australian Central Bank Holds Rates Steady
item.description: In keeping the main interest rate at 2.5 percent, the Reserve Bank of Australia said it saw signs that past rate cuts had their intended effect.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Prodding, U.S. State Department Labels Kunming Attack ‘Terrorism’
item.description: Questioned by reporters, a State Department spokeswoman, Jen Psaki, called the deadly attack in Kunming a terrorist attack, after the Chinese state news media accused overseas news agencies of failing to do so.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Jen Psaki, U.S. State Department spokeswoman.

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: 2 Officers Sentenced to 10 Years for 2010 Killing
item.description: A court sentenced two police officers for the killing of a man whose death was one of the sparks that set off the uprising against President Hosni Mubarak the following year.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: Migrant Dies in Deportation Center Riot
item.description: The detainee died, and nine others were injured, in a stampede during a riot at a Saudi detention center for migrant workers awaiting deportation, the police said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Informal Talks Held With North Korean Envoys
item.description: Diplomats from Japan and North Korea talked for two hours on Monday in an informal meeting that could be a first step toward the reopening of an official dialogue between the countries.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: U.N. Debates the Breadth of a Mission in the Central African Republic
item.description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, recommended up to 10,000 soldiers, plus 1,820 police officers to protect civilians.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: Explosion Kills 3 Police Officers, Ministry Says
item.description: The officers were killed Monday during a protest near Bahrain’s capital, Manama, while trying to disperse a group of protesters who were blocking road, the Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Report People From Xinjiang, Police Say After Deadly Attack
item.description: A police station in the southern region of Guangxi has called on citizens to report any people from Xinjiang in their midst, after attackers believed to be from the far western region killed at least 29 people on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A sign in the airport in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province, reading "Urumqi: Special Security Channel," alerts travelers heading for the capital of Xinjiang that they have to proceed through a separate security line.

item.title: Biting Words but No Action at Security Council Meeting
item.description: The United Nations Security Council’s emergency meeting was its third in four days on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: News Analysis: As Prime Russian Trading Partner, Germany Appears Crucial to Ending Crisis
item.description: With Russia’s economy in a downturn, Germany could be in a prime spot to leverage a peaceful end to the upheaval in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: Angela Merkel and Vladimir Putin in 2012. Russia’s struggling economy could provide Germany with diplomatic leverage.

item.title: Top Russians Face Sanctions by U.S. for Crimea Crisis
item.description: The Obama administration suspended military ties to Russia, including exercises, port visits and planning meetings, just a day after calling off trade talks.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arriving in St. Petersburg with other officials on Monday to watch a military exercise.

item.title: As Obama and Netanyahu Meet, Ukraine Becomes a Focus of Conversation
item.description: The West’s standoff with Russia could complicate American efforts to curb Iran’s nuclear program, resolve Syria’s civil war and even broker peace between Israel and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: From Russia, ‘Tourists’ Stir the Protests
item.description: “Protest tourists” from across the border are joining demonstrations by ethnic Russians in southern and eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pavel Gubarev, center, leader of the pro-Russia People’s Militia of Donbass, spoke to supporters in the Parliament chamber in Donetsk, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Kiev Cites Campaign of Pressure by Russia
item.description: The new government of Ukraine accused Russia of deploying 16,000 troops to Crimean Peninsula and demanding that it surrender or face armed assault — a claim Russia denied.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
